verses.text: Adam, Seth, Enosh,
verses.comment: The genealogy begins with Adam, designating him as the first man created. This emphasizes the continuity of God's salvation history through a real historical lineage.

verses.text: Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,
verses.comment: This list follows the Genesis genealogies, showing careful preservation of tradition. It highlights the importance of roots and identity through ancestors.

verses.text: Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
verses.comment: Enoch is specially noted elsewhere as a man who walked with God and was taken up, a foreshadowing of later teachings on sanctity and heavenly reward.

verses.text: Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.comment: Noah’s sons represent the origin of the nations after the flood. The preservation of humanity through the Ark is pointed to as an early image of salvation and covenant.

verses.text: The sons of Japheth: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
verses.comment: Japheth’s descendants populated many regions, showing God’s concern for all peoples, not only for Israel.

verses.text: The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah.
verses.comment: These names later became associated with various peoples. The genealogy also serves to demonstrate divine providence over human history.

verses.text: The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
verses.comment: Javan’s descendants are connected to maritime peoples and trade—Tarshish often appears in prophetic imagery (see Isa. 2:16).

verses.text: The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
verses.comment: Ham’s descendants fill much of Africa and Canaan, highlighting the wide reach of the ancient world.

verses.text: The sons of Cush: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raamah, and Sabteca. The sons of Raamah: Sheba and Dedan.
verses.comment: The double branching signifies growth and expansion. The names Sheba and Dedan later become symbols of trade and wealth.

verses.text: Cush fathered Nimrod. He began to be a mighty one on the earth.
verses.comment: Nimrod is recognized as an early king and hunter, representing both human ambition and the start of organized civilization.

verses.text: Mizraim fathered the Ludim, the Anamim, the Lehabim, the Naphtuhim,
verses.comment: These groups comprise ancient peoples in the region of Egypt and North Africa, connecting biblical history to wider ancient cultures.

verses.text: the Pathrusim, the Casluhim (from whom the Philistines came), and the Caphtorim.
verses.comment: The link to the Philistines points to significant later enemies of Israel and shows the depth of ancient rivalries.

verses.text: Canaan fathered Sidon, his firstborn, then Heth,
verses.comment: Sidon became a major city, later known for its interaction with Israel. Early nations often become symbols of sin or wisdom depending on later biblical context.

verses.text: and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
verses.comment: These tribes would oppose God’s chosen people, and their inclusion sets up the narrative tension in Israel’s story.

verses.text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
verses.comment: The wide range of groups further highlights the spread and complexity of ancient populations.

verses.text: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
verses.comment: The genealogies serve as a reminder of God’s universal creativity, laying a foundation for both judgment and redemption.

verses.text: The sons of Shem: Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
verses.comment: From Shem would come Abraham and eventually Israel, showing how God’s plan works through specific historical people.

verses.text: The sons of Aram: Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.
verses.comment: Uz becomes significant as Job’s homeland (Job 1:1), linking wisdom literature to this genealogy.

verses.text: Arphaxad fathered Shelah, Shelah fathered Eber.
verses.comment: Eber is considered the ancestor of the Hebrews—later on, this connection brings us closer to Abraham, and ultimately to the Messiah.

verses.text: To Eber were born two sons: Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided, and Joktan.
verses.comment: The division of the earth may refer to the scattering after Babel. The genealogies serve as testimony to God’s sovereignty over creation.

verses.text: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
verses.comment: The line of Joktan connects to Arabian tribes, expanding the map of biblical peoples.

verses.text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
verses.comment: The descendants continue, showing the fruitfulness and spread of humanity.

verses.text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
verses.comment: Sheba is a notable name, later visited by the queen in Solomon’s time (1 Kings 10:1).

verses.text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
verses.comment: Ophir’s riches are symbolic of divine favor and provision. Jobab's name is associated with wisdom traditions.

verses.text: Shem, Arphaxad, Shelah,
verses.comment: Returning to the line of Shem sets the focus on the story that leads to Abraham, the covenant, and eventually Christ.

verses.text: Eber, Peleg, Reu,
verses.comment: The genealogical repetition highlights the sacred transmission of generational blessing, a theme found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Serug, Nahor, Terah,
verses.comment: Terah is the father of Abraham, signifying the transition toward God’s chosen people.

verses.text: Abram, that is, Abraham.
verses.comment: The change from Abram to Abraham reflects God's covenant and promise. Abraham becomes a type of faith for both Jews and Christians (Rom. 4:1-3).

verses.text: The sons of Abraham: Isaac and Ishmael.
verses.comment: The two sons mark the distinction between the nations and the line of promise. Isaac’s line is crucial for God’s redemptive plan.

verses.text: These are their descendants: The firstborn of Ishmael, Nebaioth, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
verses.comment: The descendants of Ishmael become Arab tribes, illustrating the vastness of God’s creation and care for all nations.

verses.text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema,
verses.comment: Many of these names are later associated with regions or towns mentioned by prophets, showing continuity of history.

verses.text: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These are the sons of Ishmael.
verses.comment: The completeness of the list demonstrates the inclusivity of divine providence—the Lord doesn’t forget any tribe.

verses.text: The sons of Keturah, Abraham's concubine: she bore Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. The sons of Jokshan: Sheba and Dedan.
verses.comment: Keturah’s sons broaden the scope of Abraham’s legacy. Midian’s descendants become significant later in the Exodus story.

verses.text: The sons of Midian: Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the descendants of Keturah.
verses.comment: This genealogy is a testament to the fruitfulness connected with faithfulness to God.

verses.text: Abraham fathered Isaac. The sons of Isaac: Esau and Israel.
verses.comment: Jacob (Israel) becomes the father of the twelve tribes, the chosen people. The narrative moves closer to the formation of God’s priestly nation.

verses.text: The sons of Esau: Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
verses.comment: Esau’s descendants form the Edomites, perennial neighbors and adversaries of Israel.

verses.text: The sons of Eliphaz: Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, and by Timna, Amalek.
verses.comment: Amalek becomes a major adversary of Israel in the desert, reflecting ongoing spiritual conflict.

verses.text: The sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
verses.comment: The repetition of names highlights historical continuity, preparing for national rivalries in later narratives.

verses.text: The sons of Seir: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
verses.comment: These tribal chiefs formed the inhabitants of the land before Israel, with Lotan and others often cited as 'dukes.'

verses.text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
verses.comment: These sons represent important tribal figures in Edomite history.

verses.text: The sons of Lotan: Hori and Homam. The sister of Lotan was Timna.
verses.comment: Highlighting Timna’s name, the text credits significant women in the formation of foreign tribes.

verses.text: The sons of Shobal: Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. The sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah.
verses.comment: The detailed lineages connect major regional tribes to specific ancestors, strengthening the biblical record's reliability.

verses.text: The sons of Anah: Dishon. The sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
verses.comment: Names reflect the complexity of Edomite tribal leadership and offer historical context for later conflicts.

verses.text: The sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan. The sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
verses.comment: The close attention to genealogy underpins the importance of heritage and the passing of leadership.

verses.text: These are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelites: Bela son of Beor; his city was Dinhabah.
verses.comment: Chronicles emphasizes God’s timing—that the Edomites had kings before Israel, foreshadowing Israel’s future monarchy and a divinely ordained order.

verses.text: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah became king.
verses.comment: Each king’s succession underlines order and governance, themes picked up in later descriptions of Israel’s kings.

verses.text: When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites became king.
verses.comment: Teman is later referenced by prophets as a place of wisdom (Jer. 49:7).

verses.text: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the fields of Moab, became king; his city was Avith.
verses.comment: Hadad’s military victory connects Edom to the greater regional conflicts that affect Israel’s history.

verses.text: When Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah became king.
verses.comment: The orderly succession underscores the importance of legitimate rule.

verses.text: When Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the river became king.
verses.comment: The mention of rivers often symbolizes prosperity and blessing throughout Scripture.

verses.text: When Shaul died, Baal-Hanan son of Akbor became king.
verses.comment: Baal-Hanan’s name reflects the interaction between Yahweh’s people and their neighbors.

verses.text: When Baal-Hanan died, Hadad became king; his city was Pai. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred, daughter of Mezahab.
verses.comment: References to queens show women’s importance in ancient dynastic continuity.

verses.text: Then Hadad died. These were the chiefs of Edom: chief Timna, chief Aliah, chief Jetheth,
verses.comment: The tribal chiefs listed here reflect the structured governance, mirrored in the twelve tribes of Israel.

verses.text: chief Oholibamah, chief Elah, chief Pinon, chief Kenaz, chief Teman, chief Mibzar, chief Magdiel, and chief Iram. These were the chiefs of Edom.
verses.comment: The enumeration finishes with a completeness that points to God’s wisdom in order and governance. It also sets up the conflict and distinction between Israel and neighboring peoples, paving the way for fulfillment in God’s chosen line which ultimately leads to Christ.
